title: Project: Mad Libs Generator
description:
## Goal
First Python Starter project - learners create a funny story generator.

## Concepts Introduced
- Variables (storing words)
- input() function (getting user input)
- print() function (showing output)
- String concatenation/f-strings
- Comments

## Project Flow
1. Show the finished Mad Lib running
2. Explain what we're building
3. Step-by-step: get noun, verb, adjective, etc.
4. Combine into silly story
5. Challenge: Make your own Mad Lib template

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Interactive code blocks that run in browser
- [ ] 'Explain This' on each code section
- [ ] Final working Mad Libs game
- [ ] Challenge extension for creativity
- [ ] ~15 min to complete

title: Project: Text Adventure Game
description:
## Goal
Capstone Python Starter project - a choose-your-own-adventure game.

## Concepts Introduced
- Dictionaries for game state/rooms
- Functions for game actions
- Game loops
- State management
- Combining all previous concepts

## Project Flow
1. Design simple 3-room adventure
2. Create room dictionary with descriptions
3. Build navigation system
4. Add items and inventory
5. Create win/lose conditions
6. Challenge: Expand your world!

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working text adventure
- [ ] At least 3 connected rooms
- [ ] Player can win/lose
- [ ] Combines loops, conditionals, functions, dicts
- [ ] ~30 min to complete

title: Python Starter: Learn by Making (Instructables-style)
description:
## Vision
Create a fun, hands-on Python intro course that comes BEFORE the current Python Basics modules. Think 'Instructables for Python' - learners build cool stuff immediately and learn concepts through doing.

## Philosophy
- **Immediate gratification** - Every project produces something fun/useful
- **Browser-based** - All projects run in Pyodide, no setup required
- **Skippable** - Experienced folks can jump to Python Basics
- **Progressive** - Each project introduces new concepts naturally

## Target Projects (7 mini-projects)
1. **Mad Libs Generator** - strings, input(), print()
2. **Number Guessing Game** - while loops, conditionals, random
3. **Rock Paper Scissors** - if/elif/else, game logic
4. **Simple Calculator** - functions, operators, user input
5. **Password Generator** - lists, random.choice(), string methods
6. **ASCII Art Maker** - loops, string formatting, creativity
7. **Text Adventure Game** - dictionaries, functions, game state

## Technical Constraints
- Must run in Pyodide (browser)
- Each project: 15-30 min to complete
- Minimal theory, maximum doing
- 'Explain This' buttons for deeper dives

## Success Metrics
- Learners complete 3+ projects before moving to Modules
- High engagement (tutor questions per project)
- Smooth transition to formal curriculum

title: Project: AI Art Prompt Lab
description:
## Goal
Creative workshop: master the art of AI prompting.

## Concepts Introduced
- Prompt engineering techniques
- Specificity and detail
- Style transfer in language
- Iterative refinement
- AI as creative collaborator

## Project Flow
1. Basic prompt → see result
2. Add details → better result
3. Experiment with styles
4. Learn prompt patterns that work
5. Create your own prompt templates
6. Challenge: Chain prompts together

## Interactive Elements
- Side-by-side prompt comparison
- Prompt template builder
- Gallery of user creations

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clear prompt engineering techniques
- [ ] Interactive experimentation
- [ ] Creative and fun
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Project: Build Your Own Chatbot
description:
## Goal
Capstone AI Starter project - create a chatbot from scratch.

## Concepts Introduced
- Rule-based vs ML approaches
- Intent detection
- Response generation
- Conversation flow
- Combining everything learned

## Project Flow
1. Start with simple if/else chatbot
2. Add pattern matching
3. Integrate with WebLLM for smarts
4. Create custom personality
5. Handle edge cases gracefully
6. Challenge: Multi-turn conversation

## Approaches Covered
- Rules: if 'hello' → 'Hi there!'
- Keywords: look for important words
- ML: let the model figure it out
- Hybrid: rules + ML together

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working chatbot
- [ ] Compare rule-based vs ML
- [ ] Custom personality option
- [ ] Ready for CS50 AI!
- [ ] ~30 min to complete

title: Mobile-friendly navigation with hamburger menu
description: Navigation needs: 1) Hamburger menu for mobile screens, 2) Show all pages correctly (How It Works is missing from nav)
close_reason: Implemented hamburger menu for mobile with animated icon and dropdown nav

title: Local model support: Ollama, MLX, llama.cpp
description: Add backend options for local LLM inference beyond WebLLM
close_reason: Added support for Ollama and OpenAI-compatible APIs (MLX, llama.cpp)

title: Project: Recommendation Engine
description:
## Goal
Build a 'You might also like...' system.

## Concepts Introduced
- Similarity (how alike are two things?)
- User preferences as data
- Collaborative filtering intuition
- Content-based recommendations
- Real-world AI applications

## Project Flow
1. Demo: rate some movies, get recommendations
2. How does Netflix know? Similar users!
3. Build simple similarity calculator
4. Find 'users like you'
5. Recommend what they liked
6. Challenge: Content-based approach

## Interactive Elements
- Movie/book rating interface
- Similarity visualization
- 'Users like you' display

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working recommendation demo
- [ ] Clear similarity explanation
- [ ] Connection to real products
- [ ] ~25 min to complete

title: Project: Sentiment Detector
description:
## Goal
Build an AI that detects if text is positive or negative.

## Concepts Introduced
- Classification (sorting into categories)
- Training data (examples teach the AI)
- Features (what the AI looks at)
- Accuracy (how often it's right)
- Overfitting preview (memorizing vs learning)

## Project Flow
1. Demo: type text, see sentiment score
2. How does it work? Word counting!
3. Build simple keyword-based detector
4. Compare to ML-based approach (scikit-learn)
5. Challenge: Add 'neutral' category

## Interactive Elements
- Live sentiment meter as you type
- Show which words triggered positive/negative
- Confusion matrix visualization

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working sentiment detector
- [ ] Visual explanation of classification
- [ ] Comparison: rules vs ML
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Project: Rock Paper Scissors
description:
## Goal
Classic RPS game against the computer.

## Concepts Introduced
- if/elif/else chains
- random.choice() from a list
- Game logic and win conditions
- User input validation
- Play again loops

## Project Flow
1. Demo the game
2. Get player choice
3. Generate computer choice
4. Determine winner with conditionals
5. Challenge: Add Lizard Spock variant

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working RPS game
- [ ] Clear win/lose/tie messages
- [ ] Play again option
- [ ] ~15 min to complete

title: Learning-first AI tutor modes
description: Implement Guide Mode (Socratic) and Solution Mode with UI toggle
close_reason: Implemented Guide mode (Socratic) and Solution mode (direct) with mode-specific prompts

title: Project: Password Generator
description:
## Goal
Create strong random passwords with customization options.

## Concepts Introduced
- Lists and string constants
- random.choice() and random.sample()
- String concatenation in loops
- Boolean flags for options
- len() function

## Project Flow
1. Define character sets (letters, numbers, symbols)
2. Get desired password length
3. Build password character by character
4. Add options (include symbols? numbers?)
5. Challenge: Password strength meter

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Generates random passwords
- [ ] Customizable length
- [ ] Option toggles work
- [ ] ~15 min to complete

title: Project: Number Guessing Game
description:
## Goal
Second Python Starter project - classic guessing game with hints.

## Concepts Introduced
- while loops (keep guessing until correct)
- Conditionals (too high, too low, correct!)
- random module (random.randint)
- Comparison operators (<, >, ==)
- Counter variables

## Project Flow
1. Demo the finished game
2. Import random, generate secret number
3. Build the guessing loop
4. Add 'too high/too low' hints
5. Track number of guesses
6. Challenge: Add difficulty levels

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working game in browser
- [ ] Clear hint messages
- [ ] Guess counter
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Project: Chat with Sluggy (WebLLM Intro)
description:
## Goal
First AI Starter project - meet the AI that runs in your browser.

## Concepts Introduced
- What is an LLM? (Language Model basics)
- Prompts and responses
- Context and conversation
- Temperature and creativity
- The AI is predicting 'what comes next'

## Project Flow
1. Open Sluggy chat, ask a question
2. Peek behind the curtain - what's happening?
3. Experiment with different prompts
4. Try the same prompt multiple times (randomness)
5. Challenge: Make Sluggy adopt a persona

## Interactive Elements
- Side-by-side: your prompt → AI's thinking → response
- Temperature slider to see effect
- Token visualization

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clear explanation of how LLMs work
- [ ] Interactive prompt experiments
- [ ] Demystifies the 'magic'
- [ ] ~15 min to complete

title: Fix link contrast in dark mode for WCAG compliance
description: Links on dark background have poor contrast (purple/blue on dark). Need minimum 4.5:1 ratio per WCAG AA. Affects how-it-works.html Resources section and other pages with links.
close_reason: Fixed link colors with WCAG compliant contrast in both light and dark modes

title: Add CS50 AI with Python course track
description:
## Goal
Add Harvard's CS50 AI with Python as an advanced track for learners who complete the Python basics modules.

## Completed Work
- [x] Created cs50-ai.html landing page with 7-week course overview
- [x] Updated tutor-flow.js to detect AI track and inject CS50 AI context
- [x] Added CS50 AI link to index.html navigation
- [x] Added CSS for new components (hero-badge, info-grid, project-list, library-card)
- [x] Created modules/ai-week-0.html (Search: DFS, BFS, A*, Minimax)

## Remaining Work
- [ ] Create ai-week-1.html (Knowledge)
- [ ] Create ai-week-2.html (Uncertainty)
- [ ] Create ai-week-3.html (Optimization)
- [ ] Create ai-week-4.html (Learning)
- [ ] Create ai-week-5.html (Neural Networks)
- [ ] Create ai-week-6.html (Language)

## Technical Notes
- PocketFlow context injection detects isAITrack via URL pattern
- AI tutor switches persona and knowledge base based on page location
- Some libraries (TensorFlow) marked as Local Only since they cannot run in Pyodide

title: Replace certification jargon with beginner-friendly labels
description: Change PCEP/Google tags to Beginner/Intermediate/Advanced with time estimates

title: Project: Simple Calculator
description:
## Goal
Build a calculator that does basic math operations.

## Concepts Introduced
- Functions (def, parameters, return)
- Multiple conditionals for operations
- Type conversion (int, float)
- Error handling basics (try/except)
- Menu-driven programs

## Project Flow
1. Create add, subtract, multiply, divide functions
2. Build menu to select operation
3. Get two numbers from user
4. Call appropriate function
5. Challenge: Add more operations (power, modulo)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working calculator with +, -, *, /
- [ ] Division by zero handled
- [ ] Clean menu interface
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Project: ASCII Art Maker
description:
## Goal
Create text-based art and patterns using loops.

## Concepts Introduced
- Nested for loops
- String multiplication (* operator)
- Print formatting and alignment
- Pattern recognition
- Creative expression in code

## Project Flow
1. Print simple shapes (rectangle, triangle)
2. Understand loop-to-row relationship
3. Build pyramid pattern
4. Create custom ASCII art
5. Challenge: Animate with time.sleep()

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Multiple pattern examples
- [ ] Interactive pattern builder
- [ ] Visual understanding of loops
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Improve quiz feedback with explanations
description: Show correct answers and explain why after quiz submission

title: Project: Word Predictor
description:
## Goal
Build a simple 'autocomplete' that predicts the next word.

## Concepts Introduced
- N-grams (word sequences)
- Probability (what comes next most often?)
- Training on text data
- Language patterns
- This is how early chatbots worked!

## Project Flow
1. Demo: start typing, see predictions
2. Count word pairs in sample text
3. Build probability table
4. Predict most likely next word
5. Challenge: Use bigrams vs trigrams

## Interactive Elements
- Live prediction as you type
- Show probability distribution
- Visualize n-gram counts

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Working word predictor
- [ ] Visual n-gram explanation
- [ ] Connection to LLMs ('this but bigger!')
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: Project: Teach a Robot to Sort
description:
## Goal
Visual introduction to classification with a sorting game.

## Concepts Introduced
- Features (what makes things different)
- Decision boundaries (where to draw the line)
- Training vs testing (learning vs exam)
- k-Nearest Neighbors intuition
- The AI learns patterns from examples

## Project Flow
1. Interactive: drag items into categories
2. What features did YOU use to sort?
3. Teach the robot your rules
4. Watch it sort new items
5. Challenge: Harder sorting tasks

## Interactive Elements
- Drag-and-drop sorting interface
- Decision boundary visualization
- Feature importance display

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Visual sorting game
- [ ] Clear feature explanation
- [ ] k-NN intuition (look at neighbors)
- [ ] ~20 min to complete

title: AI Starter: AI You Can Touch (Instructables-style)
description:
## Vision
Create a hands-on AI intro course that comes BEFORE CS50 AI. Demystify AI through interactive projects that run in the browser. Think 'Instructables for AI' - touch it, play with it, understand it.

## Philosophy
- **Demystify AI** - Show what's really happening, not magic
- **Browser-based** - WebLLM for chat, scikit-learn via Pyodide for ML
- **Interactive** - Every concept has a 'try it yourself' component
- **Progressive** - Build intuition before formal theory

## Target Projects (7 mini-projects)
1. **Chat with Sluggy** - Meet WebLLM, prompt basics
2. **Sentiment Detector** - Is this text happy or sad?
3. **Word Predictor** - N-grams and probability intro
4. **Teach a Robot to Sort** - Simple classification visual
5. **Recommendation Engine** - 'You might also like...'
6. **AI Art Prompt Lab** - Creative prompting workshop
7. **Build Your Own Chatbot** - Rules vs ML approaches

## Technical Constraints
- WebLLM for LLM projects (already integrated)
- scikit-learn via Pyodide for ML demos
- Visual/interactive explanations
- No heavy model training (use pre-trained)

## Success Metrics
- Learners gain AI intuition before CS50 AI theory
- Can explain 'how AI works' in simple terms
- Confident to tackle CS50 AI curriculum
